Post Content:
📢 Job Opening: QC Incoming Inspector📍 Location: Pest Food Factory 📞 Contact: 081 993 575 📧 Email: soknengtuy1@gmail.comPest Food Factory is hiring! We’re seeking a detail-oriented, responsible, and food safety-focused professional to join our Quality Control team as a QC Incoming Inspector.In this role, you’ll ensure that all incoming raw materials, packaging, and food components meet strict internal and external standards before they reach production.🔍 Key Work Activities1. Documentation VerificationReview COAs, MSDS, lab reports, and certifications for complianceConfirm expiry dates and third-party lab validationsAssess food-grade declarations and physical quality parameters2. Raw Material Quality ControlInspect for contamination, spoilage, dimensions, and moistureVerify compliance with chemical and microbiological standardsInitiate third-party lab testing when necessary3. Packaging Material AssessmentPlastic Bags: Evaluate size, labeling, and safety certificationStickers & Labels: Ensure food safety and visual complianceCartons: Check structure, hygiene, and correct labeling4. Transport & Hygiene InspectionAssess truck/container cleanliness, temperature, and seal integrityEnsure absence of pests or foreign materials5. Inspection Reporting & ApprovalRecord inspection results in reports for QA Manager reviewMake informed decisions on product release or rejection6. Label ImplementationApply correct status: Approved / On-Hold / Rejected based on results7. Loading SupervisionOversee container hygiene and product integrity during loadingPrevent mix-ups and contamination risks✅ Candidate RequirementsBackground in Food Science, Quality Assurance, or a related fieldKnowledge of ISO 9001, ISO 22000, FDA, and food safety standardsStrong attention to detail and accurate documentation skillsAbility to work independently and collaborate across departments

We’re seeking a detail-oriented, responsible, and food safety-focused professional to join our Quality Control team as a QC Incoming Inspector.In this role, you’ll ensure that all incoming raw materials, packaging, and food components meet strict internal and external standards before they reach production.🔍 Key Work Activities1. Documentation VerificationReview COAs, MSDS, lab reports, and certifications for complianceConfirm expiry dates and third-party lab validationsAssess food-grade declarations and physical quality parameters2. Raw Material Quality ControlInspect for contamination, spoilage, dimensions, and moistureVerify compliance with chemical and microbiological standardsInitiate third-party lab testing when necessary3. Packaging Material AssessmentPlastic Bags: Evaluate size, labeling, and safety certificationStickers & Labels: Ensure food safety and visual complianceCartons: Check structure, hygiene, and correct labeling4. Work closely with developers, project managers, and other team members to ensure timely delivery of quality software.8. Help in performing user acceptance testing (UAT) and provide feedback on the product.9. Learn and follow standard QA procedures and processes.10. Skills and Qualifications:11. A degree in Computer Science, Information Technology, or related fields.12. Basic knowledge of Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) and Software Testing Life Cycle (STLC).13. Understanding of manual testing techniques and methodologies.14. Familiarity with testing concepts such as functional testing, regression testing, and UAT.15. Knowledge of bug tracking tools (e.g., JIRA, Bugzilla) is a plus.16. Good communication skills and the ability to work effectively in a team.17. Attention to detail and strong analytical skills.18. Willingness to learn and adapt to new tools and technologies.Desirable Skills (Optional):1. Familiarity with SQL for basic database testing.2. Basic knowledge of automation testing tools (e.g., Selenium) is a plus but not mandatory.3. Knowledge of Agile methodology is a plus.

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

🌟 We’re Hiring: QA Engineer (Korean Speaker)📍 Location: Jakarta, Indonesia (On-site + Hybrid Work)Are you passionate about quality and love making great products even better?OpsNow are expanding our team and looking for a sharp, curious, and driven QA Engineer to help us deliver world-class cloud management services.💼 What You'll Be Doing• Guarantee the quality of OpsNow services through rigorous testing and automation.• Design and execute scalable validation and quality assurance processes.• Analyze test results, squash bugs, and continuously improve performance.• Collaborate with developers, designers, and product managers to ensure outstanding product releases.🔑 What We’re Looking For• Proficient Korean communication skills (written & spoken).• Degree in IT-related fields.• Understanding of software development lifecycles (SDLC).• Familiarity with QA processes, test design, and defect management.• A curious mind, strong logic, and sharp problem-solving skills.• Team player with excellent communication and collaboration instincts.• Detail-obsessed with a strong sense of ownership.💡 Bonus Points If You Have• Experience testing web-based services (front-end & back-end).• Hands-on experience with B2B, B2C, and SaaS platforms.• Skilled in test planning, strategy, defect tracking, and reporting.• Automation experience using Playwright, Postman, or similar tools.• QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

🌟 We’re Hiring: QA Engineer (Korean Speaker)📍 Location: Jakarta, Indonesia (On-site + Hybrid Work)Are you passionate about quality and love making great products even better?OpsNow are expanding our team and looking for a sharp, curious, and driven QA Engineer to help us deliver world-class cloud management services.💼 What You'll Be Doing• Guarantee the quality of OpsNow services through rigorous testing and automation.• Design and execute scalable validation and quality assurance processes.• Analyze test results, squash bugs, and continuously improve performance.• Collaborate with developers, designers, and product managers to ensure outstanding product releases.🔑 What We’re Looking For• Proficient Korean communication skills (written & spoken).• Degree in IT-related fields.• Understanding of software development lifecycles (SDLC).• Familiarity with QA processes, test design, and defect management.• A curious mind, strong logic, and sharp problem-solving skills.• Team player with excellent communication and collaboration instincts.• Detail-obsessed with a strong sense of ownership.💡 Bonus Points If You Have• Experience testing web-based services (front-end & back-end).• Hands-on experience with B2B, B2C, and SaaS platforms.• Skilled in test planning, strategy, defect tracking, and reporting.• Automation experience using Playwright, Postman, or similar tools.• QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture

QC, QA, or TQM? What’s the REAL difference?Most people even professionals use these terms interchangeably—but in reality, they define entirely different approaches to quality, productivity and excellence in the industry.—Here’s a quick breakdown that every engineer, manager, and recruiter should know.1. Quality Control (QC):→ Think of it as the “hashtag#Gatekeeper”Purpose: Detect & fix defectsFocus: ProductResponsibility: Inspectors & QC Team2. Quality Assurance (QA):→ The “hashtag#Process hashtag#Guardian”Purpose: Prevent defects before they happenFocus: ProcessResponsibility: Cross-functional QA Team3. Total Quality Management (TQM):→ The “hashtag#Culture hashtag#of hashtag#Quality”Purpose: Continuous improvement & customer delightFocus: Whole OrganizationResponsibility: Everyone—from top management to shop floor peoples!Why does it matter?Understanding these terms is more than theory—it shows you speak the language of operations, leadership, and customer value.Who gets this right doesn’t just reduce defects—they build trust, efficiency, and a brand customers believe in.I’ve applied these concepts to real-world scenarios in QA & QC management, and trust me—they make a difference on the floor.Let’s build products that speak quality from Day 1—not just at the final check.hashtag#QAQC hashtag#ShahbazTalks hashtag#QualityControl hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#TQM hashtag#ManufacturingExcellence hashtag#ProcessImprovement hashtag#Lean hashtag#Engineering hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#Hiring hashtag#JobSearchWhich one do you focus on in your company? Let’s share your insights

Does your team have Testers or QAs?This question says a lot about your development maturity.In agile development, the distinction between a Software Tester and a Quality Assurance (QA) professional directly impacts your team’s efficiency, quality, and delivery speed.Testers usually focus on executing functional tests after development is complete.They validate acceptance criteria and report defects.But QAs play a much more strategic role: •	Participate early in backlog refinement and planning. •	Influence the development process through TDD, BDD, shift-left testing, and continuous automation. •	Monitor quality metrics, test coverage, and potential risk areas.While a Tester works on the “output”, a QA focuses on the “cause.”And the market is evolving fast:High-performing teams have QAs who ensure quality is built in, not just tested in.What about your team? Is quality treated as everyone’s responsibility, or just the tester’s?Let’s exchange insights in the comments!hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#ShiftLeft hashtag#DevOps hashtag#AgileDevelopment hashtag#TDD hashtag#BDD hashtag#TestingStrategy hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityCulture
